Appendix A Modelling metals and the distortion

As we assume all forest pixels correspond to LyŒ±ùõº\alpha¬†absorption, correlations involving metals are assigned to the wrong bin in comoving coordinates due to one (for LyŒ±√ómùõºùëö\alpha\times m and QSO√ómabsentùëö\times m) or both (for m√ómùëöùëöm\times m) tracers being assigned the wrong redshift. This is modelled through a metal matrix which transforms the model correlations computed using the correct separations, r~||\tilde{r}_{||} and r~‚ä•subscript~ùëübottom\tilde{r}_{\bot}, to the measured model correlations:

ŒæAmetal=‚àëBMA‚ÄãB‚ÄãŒæmetal‚Äã(r~||‚Äã(B),r~‚ä•‚Äã(B)),\xi^{\mathrm{metal}}_{A}=\sum_{B}M_{AB}\xi^{\mathrm{metal}}(\tilde{r}_{||}(B),\tilde{r}_{\bot}(B)), (15)

where Aùê¥A and BùêµB are comoving separation bins, and the metal matrix is given by:

MA‚ÄãB=1WA‚Äã‚àë(i,j)‚ààA,(i,j)‚ààBwi‚Äãwj,subscriptùëÄùê¥ùêµ1subscriptùëäùê¥subscriptformulae-sequenceùëñùëóùê¥ùëñùëóùêµsubscriptùë§ùëñsubscriptùë§ùëóM_{AB}=\frac{1}{W_{A}}\sum_{(i,j)\in A,(i,j)\in B}w_{i}w_{j}, (16)

where (i,j)‚ààAùëñùëóùê¥(i,j)\in A refers to separations computed using the assigned redshifts (assuming only LyŒ±ùõº\alpha¬†absorption), and (i,j)‚ààBùëñùëóùêµ(i,j)\in B refers to separations computed using the true redshifts of each tracer. The weights, wisubscriptùë§ùëñw_{i}, are given by the inverse variance of Œ¥qsubscriptùõøùëû\delta_{q} (see du Mas des Bourboux et¬†al. 2020), and WA=‚àë(i,j)‚ààAwi‚Äãwjsubscriptùëäùê¥subscriptùëñùëóùê¥subscriptùë§ùëñsubscriptùë§ùëóW_{A}=\sum_{(i,j)\in A}w_{i}w_{j}. Note that we drop the quasar specification from our notation, as the sums are understood to be over all pixels in each comoving separation bin.

In order to model the distortion due to continuum fitting errors, we need to apply the projection Œ∑i‚ÄãjqsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëñùëóùëû\eta_{ij}^{q} to the modelled flux fluctuation Œ¥qtsubscriptsuperscriptùõøùë°ùëû\delta^{t}_{q} (Equation 2). This is done by using Œ∑i‚ÄãjqsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëñùëóùëû\eta_{ij}^{q} to construct a distortion matrix that is applied to the theoretical model correlations, Œæautotsuperscriptsubscriptùúâautoùë°\xi_{\mathrm{auto}}^{t} and Œæcrosstsuperscriptsubscriptùúâcrossùë°\xi_{\mathrm{cross}}^{t} to give the projected correlation function:

Œæ^A=‚àëBDA‚ÄãB‚ÄãŒæBt,subscript^ùúâùê¥subscriptùêµsubscriptùê∑ùê¥ùêµsuperscriptsubscriptùúâùêµùë°\hat{\xi}_{A}=\sum_{B}D_{AB}\xi_{B}^{t}, (17)

where Aùê¥A is a bin of the data and BùêµB is a bin of the model. The distortion matrices for the auto and cross-correlations are given by:

DA‚ÄãBautosuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùê¥ùêµauto\displaystyle D_{AB}^{\mathrm{auto}} =WA‚àí1‚Äã‚àëi‚Äãj‚ààAwi‚Äãwj‚Äã‚àëi‚Ä≤‚Äãj‚Ä≤‚ààBŒ∑i‚Äãi‚Ä≤‚ÄãŒ∑j‚Äãj‚Ä≤,absentsuperscriptsubscriptùëäùê¥1subscriptùëñùëóùê¥subscriptùë§ùëñsubscriptùë§ùëósubscriptsuperscriptùëñ‚Ä≤superscriptùëó‚Ä≤ùêµsubscriptùúÇùëñsuperscriptùëñ‚Ä≤subscriptùúÇùëósuperscriptùëó‚Ä≤\displaystyle=W_{A}^{-1}\sum_{ij\in A}w_{i}w_{j}\sum_{i^{\prime}j^{\prime}\in B}\eta_{ii^{\prime}}\eta_{jj^{\prime}}, (18)
DA‚ÄãBcrosssuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùê¥ùêµcross\displaystyle D_{AB}^{\mathrm{cross}} =WA‚àí1‚Äã‚àëi‚Äãj‚ààAwi‚Äãwj‚Äã‚àëi‚Ä≤‚Äãj‚ààBŒ∑i‚Äãi‚Ä≤.absentsuperscriptsubscriptùëäùê¥1subscriptùëñùëóùê¥subscriptùë§ùëñsubscriptùë§ùëósubscriptsuperscriptùëñ‚Ä≤ùëóùêµsubscriptùúÇùëñsuperscriptùëñ‚Ä≤\displaystyle=W_{A}^{-1}\sum_{ij\in A}w_{i}w_{j}\sum_{i^{\prime}j\in B}\eta_{ii^{\prime}}. (19)

See Bautista et¬†al. (2017) and P√©rez-R√†fols et¬†al. (2018) for more details.

Appendix B Impact of fiducial cosmology

Our method requires the use of a fiducial cosmology, both for defining the comoving coordinate grid on which the correlations are computed, and for the template power spectrum that is used to construct the theoretical model for the LyŒ±ùõº\alpha¬†correlations. This fiducial cosmology is based on cosmic microwave background anisotropy data from the Planck satellite (Planck Collaboration et¬†al., 2016). In this appendix, we test the impact of this choice of fiducial cosmology.

We recompute the LyŒ±ùõº\alpha¬†auto and cross-correlations of one of the mocks using two different values of the matter density parameter, Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëö\Omega_{m}. The two values are Œ©m=0.27subscriptŒ©ùëö0.27\Omega_{m}=0.27 and Œ©m=0.36subscriptŒ©ùëö0.36\Omega_{m}=0.36. We then perform our standard analysis and measure Œ±psubscriptùõºp\alpha_{\mathrm{p}}¬†and œïfsubscriptitalic-œïùëì\phi_{f}, but we use different power spectrum templates to keep the fiducial Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëö\Omega_{m} value consistent in each analysis. In order to compare the results, we compute the relevant combinations of distances as derived parameters. Following Cuceu et¬†al. (2021), measurements of œïitalic-œï\phi and Œ±psubscriptùõºp\alpha_{\mathrm{p}}¬†correspond to:

AP:¬†‚Äãœï‚Äã(z)AP:¬†italic-œïùëß\displaystyle\textbf{AP: }\;\phi(z) =DM‚Äã(z)‚ÄãH‚Äã(z)[DM‚Äã(z)‚ÄãH‚Äã(z)]fid,absentsubscriptùê∑Mùëßùêªùëßsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùê∑Mùëßùêªùëßfid\displaystyle=\frac{D_{\mathrm{M}}(z)H(z)}{[D_{\mathrm{M}}(z)H(z)]_{\text{fid}}}, (20)
BAO:¬†‚ÄãŒ±p‚Äã(z)BAO:¬†subscriptùõºpùëß\displaystyle\textbf{BAO: }\;\alpha_{\mathrm{p}}(z) =DM‚Äã(z)‚ÄãDH‚Äã(z)/rd2[DM‚Äã(z)‚ÄãDH‚Äã(z)/rd2]fid,absentsubscriptùê∑Mùëßsubscriptùê∑Hùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùëüd2subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùê∑Mùëßsubscriptùê∑Hùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùëüd2fid\displaystyle=\sqrt{\frac{D_{\mathrm{M}}(z)D_{\mathrm{H}}(z)/r_{\mathrm{d}}^{2}}{[D_{\mathrm{M}}(z)D_{\mathrm{H}}(z)/r_{\mathrm{d}}^{2}]_{\text{fid}}}}, (21)

where DH=c/Hsubscriptùê∑ùêªùëêùêªD_{H}=c/H and rdsubscriptùëüùëër_{d} is the size of the sound horizon at the end of the drag epoch. Based on these equations and the relevant fiducial distances for each value of Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëö\Omega_{m}, we transform œïfsubscriptitalic-œïùëì\phi_{f}¬†into DM/DHsubscriptùê∑ùëÄsubscriptùê∑ùêªD_{M}/D_{H}, and Œ±psubscriptùõºp\alpha_{\mathrm{p}}¬†into DM‚ÄãDH/rd2subscriptùê∑ùëÄsubscriptùê∑ùêªsuperscriptsubscriptùëüùëë2D_{M}D_{H}/r_{d}^{2}.

We compare the results for the large and small values of Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëö\Omega_{m} with the one obtained from our standard analysis (using Œ©m=0.315subscriptŒ©ùëö0.315\Omega_{m}=0.315) in Figure 8. All three results give consistent measurements, however, they are not identical. This can be attributed to the fact that pixel pairs are distributed to different bins in the correlation when using different values of Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëö\Omega_{m}, because the comoving distances change. This will have an impact on the measured parameters, especially for BAO, where small changes in the correlation measurements (consistent with the expected noise) can produce large changes in the shape of the posterior (e.g. Cuceu et¬†al., 2020). Furthermore, when changing the fiducial Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëö\Omega_{m}, the smallest scale that we fit will be different for the same rminsubscriptùëüminr_{\mathrm{min}}. For example, the smaller value of Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëö\Omega_{m} leads to smaller scales being assigned larger comoving separations. This is why the size of the constraints increases as Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëö\Omega_{m} increases.202020This also means that our choice of rmin=25subscriptùëümin25r_{\mathrm{min}}=25¬†h‚àí1‚ÄãMpcsuperscript‚Ñé1Mpch^{-1}\text{Mpc}¬†is based on the Planck cosmology. Therefore, the analysis should be re-done, and a new minimum scale chosen, if we had reason to believe the real cosmology was very different from the one inferred by Planck. Nevertheless, all three results are consistent with each other even for these extreme values of Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëö\Omega_{m}.

Appendix C Other scale cuts

In Section¬†3.2 we have focused on the minimum scale fitted, rminsubscriptùëüminr_{\mathrm{min}}. However, we also have to choose the largest scale we fit for, rmaxsubscriptùëümaxr_{\mathrm{max}}. Furthermore, as our measurement is two-dimensional, we could also impose different scale cuts along or across the line-of-sight. We tested different versions of this analysis, which we summarize here.

We show the impact of changing the largest separation included in our fit, rmaxsubscriptùëümaxr_{\mathrm{max}}, in Figure 9. We perform the same type of comparison as we did for rminsubscriptùëüminr_{\mathrm{min}} in Figure 5. The scales we tested range from 140140140¬†h‚àí1‚ÄãMpcsuperscript‚Ñé1Mpch^{-1}\text{Mpc}¬†to 200200200¬†h‚àí1‚ÄãMpcsuperscript‚Ñé1Mpch^{-1}\text{Mpc}. We find that measurements of œïfsubscriptitalic-œïùëì\phi_{f}¬†are unbiased for all the rmaxsubscriptùëümaxr_{\mathrm{max}} values we have tried. Furthermore, the improvement in the constraint as we include more data is very weak. Therefore, following eBOSS, we decided to choose rmax=180subscriptùëümax180r_{\mathrm{max}}=180¬†h‚àí1‚ÄãMpcsuperscript‚Ñé1Mpch^{-1}\text{Mpc}¬†in our standard analysis.

As most of the contaminants of the LyŒ±ùõº\alpha forest¬†correlation functions have their largest impact along the line-of-sight, we also decided to test a cut in r‚ä•minsuperscriptsubscriptùëübottomminr_{\bot}^{\mathrm{min}}. This is the smallest transverse scale that we fit, and values r‚ä•min>0superscriptsubscriptùëübottommin0r_{\bot}^{\mathrm{min}}>0¬†h‚àí1‚ÄãMpcsuperscript‚Ñé1Mpch^{-1}\text{Mpc}¬†mean that we are removing the columns in the correlation that lie along the line-of-sight. The systematic error and expected statistical constraint on œïfsubscriptitalic-œïùëì\phi_{f}¬†for different values of r‚ä•minsuperscriptsubscriptùëübottomminr_{\bot}^{\mathrm{min}} are show in Figure 10. We find that removing the first correlation column along the line-of-sight (r‚ä•min=4superscriptsubscriptùëübottommin4r_{\bot}^{\mathrm{min}}=4¬†h‚àí1‚ÄãMpcsuperscript‚Ñé1Mpch^{-1}\text{Mpc}) still results in an unbiased measurement. However, removing more data after that starts to introduce a significant systematic bias.212121Note that we are plotting the absolute value of Œî‚ÄãœïŒîitalic-œï\Delta\phi. Therefore, the trend of increasing systematic bias in Figure 10 does not mean the bias is all in the same direction. This could be explained by the fact that removing the columns along the line-of-sight is degrading our ability to fit the parameters that control the contaminants (e.g. HCDs and metals). Even though these contaminants have their strongest impact along the line-of-sight, they have a small impact on the correlation even at large transverse separations. Therefore, it is still important to model them accurately. Given these results, we chose to not impose any cut in r‚ä•minsuperscriptsubscriptùëübottomminr_{\bot}^{\mathrm{min}}.

Appendix D Population constraints

As described in Section¬†3.4, when running the analysis on each of the one hundred mocks, we are restricted to using a minimizer due to computational constraints. This means that the reported constraints on the measured parameters are just estimates due to two reasons. Firstly, they assume the posterior is Gaussian around the best fitting value. Secondly, the best fit for the parameters of interest (œïfsubscriptitalic-œïùëì\phi_{f}, Œ±psubscriptùõºp\alpha_{\mathrm{p}}) is found without properly marginalizing over the nuisance parameters.222222The best fit value of œïssubscriptitalic-œïs\phi_{\mathrm{s}}¬†reported by the minimizer is conditional on the best fitting values of all the nuisance parameters. However, in the Bayesian framework, the quantity we are interested in is the value of œïssubscriptitalic-œïs\phi_{\mathrm{s}}¬†conditional on the posterior distributions of the nuisance parameters. Only in the second case is the uncertainty due to these parameters properly taken into account. While these approximations might be correct for the BAO parameters due to their lack of correlations with the nuisance parameters (Cuceu et¬†al., 2020), œïssubscriptitalic-œïs\phi_{\mathrm{s}}¬†definitely has such correlations (Appendix E). Therefore, in order to study accurate parameter constraints from the population of mocks, we need to use a sampler.

For the purposes of this appendix, we ran the sampler on correlations computed only using the LyŒ±ùõº\alpha¬†region (no LyŒ≤ùõΩ\beta¬†region) from uncontaminated synthetic data sets. These mocks do not include the effects of HCDs, metal absorption or redshift errors (they are also described in du Mas des Bourboux et¬†al., 2020). Therefore, the parameter space is much smaller, allowing for the computation of the full posterior distributions using a sampler. We performed the joint analysis of the auto and cross-correlations for all one hundred uncontaminated mocks.

In Figure 11, we show histograms of the constraints on Œ±psubscriptùõºp\alpha_{\mathrm{p}}, œïpsubscriptitalic-œïp\phi_{\mathrm{p}}, and œïssubscriptitalic-œïs\phi_{\mathrm{s}}¬†from the population of one hundred mocks. The main result is the one given by the sampler, in blue. We also plot the standard deviation of the best fitting values for each of the parameters over the population of mocks. This shows that the variance of the parameter values obtained from the one hundred realizations is consistent with the measured uncertainty in individual realizations, which means the uncertainties are properly accounted for.

We also compare results from the sampler with the estimates from the minimizer in Figure 11. While they roughly agree for the BAO parameters (Œ±psubscriptùõºp\alpha_{\mathrm{p}}¬†and œïpsubscriptitalic-œïp\phi_{\mathrm{p}}), this is not the case for œïssubscriptitalic-œïs\phi_{\mathrm{s}}. The two give different constraints, as shown by the difference between the red and blue histograms. This is not surprising given the assumptions involved in the fitter constraints. However, the variance of the œïssubscriptitalic-œïs\phi_{\mathrm{s}}¬†best fits is also different between the two (the red and blue vertical lines). This means that marginalization over the nuisance parameters is important in this case.232323In a frequentist framework, a possible solution for this would be to use these results to compute non-Gaussian Œî‚Äãœá2Œîsuperscriptùúí2\Delta\chi^{2} values in order to set more accurate confidence intervals on œïssubscriptitalic-œïs\phi_{\mathrm{s}}.

While this has been a rough test due to computational constraints, most of the parameters that œïssubscriptitalic-œïs\phi_{\mathrm{s}}¬†is correlated with are still present in uncontaminated mocks (bLy‚ÄãŒ±subscriptùëèLyùõºb_{\mathrm{Ly}\alpha}, Œ≤Ly‚ÄãŒ±subscriptùõΩLyùõº\beta_{\mathrm{Ly}\alpha} and Œ≤QSOsubscriptùõΩQSO\beta_{\mathrm{QSO}}). The main omission is bHCDsubscriptùëèHCDb_{\mathrm{HCD}}. Therefore, it would be interesting to perform this analysis with the effect of HCDs modelled in the mocks. Alternatively, future studies should perform the analysis on the fully contaminated mocks if there is access to enough computational resources.

Appendix E Parameter correlations

The advantage of BAO analyses is that they measure a well-defined feature in the correlation function. BAO scale parameters rarely have any significant correlations with the nuisance parameters, which means they are much more robust to different analysis choices when it comes to modelling contaminants. On the other hand, full-shape analyses rely on the ability to accurately model correlation functions over all the scales of interest. We have already shown in Figure 6 what biases are introduced when not modelling certain contaminants. In this appendix, we go into more detail on the sensitivity of œïssubscriptitalic-œïs\phi_{\mathrm{s}}¬†measurements to other nuisance parameters.

In Figure 12 we show the posterior distributions of the main parameters that are correlated with œïssubscriptitalic-œïs\phi_{\mathrm{s}}. The two posteriors are from the fit to the two LyŒ±ùõº\alpha¬†auto-correlations, and from the joint fit of all four correlations. The cross-correlations between LyŒ±ùõº\alpha¬†and quasars cannot be included in such a comparison because the full system of parameters is degenerate.242424See Section¬†3.1 above and Section 4 of Cuceu et¬†al. (2021) The most important correlations are between œïssubscriptitalic-œïs\phi_{\mathrm{s}}¬†and the LyŒ±ùõº\alpha¬†bias and RSD parameters, bLy‚ÄãŒ±subscriptùëèLyùõºb_{\mathrm{Ly}\alpha} and Œ≤Ly‚ÄãŒ±subscriptùõΩLyùõº\beta_{\mathrm{Ly}\alpha}. These two are highly correlated between themselves and with the HCD bias, bHCDsubscriptùëèHCDb_{\mathrm{HCD}}. The LyŒ±ùõº\alpha¬†auto-correlation provides most of the information on these parameters. On the other hand, the information on Œ≤QSOsubscriptùõΩQSO\beta_{\mathrm{QSO}} comes from the LyŒ±ùõº\alpha-QSO cross-correlation. However, a measurement of Œ≤Ly‚ÄãŒ±subscriptùõΩLyùõº\beta_{\mathrm{Ly}\alpha} (from the auto) is necessary to constrain it due to their degeneracy in the model of the cross-correlation. While we treat Œ≤QSOsubscriptùõΩQSO\beta_{\mathrm{QSO}} as a nuisance parameter in this work, future studies could also attempt to extract a measurement of the growth rate of structure from it.
